selected_quotes: New2Trip: Effect of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure on Glycemic Control in Patients w/ Obstructive Sleep Apnea …
Effect of CPAP on Glycemic Control in Patients with OSA and Type 2 Diabetes. An RCT @atscommunit…
Effect of #CPAP on Glycemic Control in Patients with #OSA and Type 2 #Diabetes. A RCT. Read abst #KTCG
Effect of CPAP on Glycemic Control in Patients with OSA and Type 2 Diabetes. An RCT @atscommunity #Sleep #RespEd
'Effect of #CPAP on Glycemic control in patients with #OSA Type 2 #diabetes' Clinical Trial.

citation.abstract:
Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a risk factor for type 2 diabetes that adversely impacts glycemic control. However, there is little evidence about the effect of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on glycemic control in diabetic patients.
To assess the effect of CPAP on glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels in patients with suboptimally controlled type 2 diabetes and OSA, and to identify its determinants.
In a 6-month, open-label, parallel, and randomized clinical trial, 50 patients with OSA and type 2 diabetes and two HbA1c levels ≥ 6.5% were randomized to CPAP (n=26) or no CPAP (control; n=24), while their usual medication for diabetes remained unchanged.
HbA1c levels, scores of the Homeostasis Model Assessment (HOMA) and Qualitative Insulin Sensitivity Check Index (QUICKI), systemic biomarkers and health-related quality of life were measured at 3 and 6 months. After 6 months, the CPAP group achieved a greater decrease in HbA1c levels compared with the control group. Insulin resistance and sensitivity measurements (in noninsulin users) and serum levels of IL-1β, IL-6 and adiponectin also improved in the CPAP group compared with the control group after 6 months. In the patients treated with CPAP, mean nocturnal oxygen saturation and baseline IL-1β were independently related with 6-month change in HbA1c levels (r2=0.510, P=0.002).
Among patients with suboptimally controlled type 2 diabetes and OSA, CPAP treatment for 6 months, when compared to a control group, resulted in improved glycemic control and insulin resistance. Clinical trial registration available at www.clinicaltrials.gov, ID NCT01801150.

Treatment with CPAP for 6 months resulted in improved glucose control.
